OOPSLA Idol A Contest to Determine the Most Innovative Idea at OOPSLA 2009 Aki Namioka Juanita Ewing 
Development Manager Software Architect Cisco Systems FIREApps anamioka@cisco.com juanitae@fireapps.com 
Abstract Contestants will have the opportunities to submit a written sum­mary of their technical innovations, 
to a panel of experts before the OOPSLA Idol Event (Panel). The experts (judges) will cull through the 
submissions and the top 5 will be asked to present their ideas to the judges. The judges will comment 
on the ideas and the audience will vote for the best submission. Categories and Subject Descriptors: 
D.0 Software, General General Terms: Innovation. Keywords: innovation, competition 1. Aki (Host) Aki 
is excited to present the first OOPSLA Idol contest. After more than 20 years in the software industry, 
and 11 OOPSLA conferences, she has seen lots of great ideas come and go. Her previous OOPSLA productions 
include From Sorceress to Scien­tist: Women in Computing and Extreme ISO!?! . She was also a member of 
the cast of No Silver Bullet . 2. Juanita (Judge) During her many years at the forefront of object-orient 
technol­ogy, Juanita Ewing has been a keen observer and critic. She has been involved in a myriad of 
ventures (interesting ventures, though not particularly successful ones), with opportunities to examine 
and evaluate a wide variety of ideas. She is looking forward to the challenges of the OOPSLA Idol competition 
and wishes good luck to all entrants! 3. Brian (Judge) Brian Foote has been programming professionally 
since the dawn of the Carter Administration, mostly in the service of academic researchers of various 
stripes. He has extensive realtime pro­gramming experience. His association with the academy has enabled 
him to dabble extensively in research. His interests include objects, program­ming, programming language 
design, reflection, metalevel archi- Copyright is held by the author/owner(s). OOPSLA 2009, October 25-29, 
2009, Orlando, Florida, USA. ACM 978-1-60558-768-4/09/10. Brian Foote E. Michael Maximilien Senior Pontificator 
Research Staff Industrial Logic IBM Almaden Research Center bigballofmud@gmail.com mmaximilien@gmail.com 
 tecture, patterns, and software devolution. His exposure to Smalltalk during his impressionable formative 
years indelibly shaped his attitudes towards software architecture and design. Brian is still one of 
five people to have attended every OOPSLA conference to-date. He is currently helping to train the next 
gen­eration of object-oriented programmers in the niceties of design patterns and iterative incremental 
methods. 4. Max (Judge) Dr. E. Michael Maximilien, is a research staff member at IBM's Almaden Research 
Center in San Jose, California. Prior to join­ing ARC, Max spent ten years at IBM's Research Triangle 
Park, N.C., in software development and architecture. Max led various small- to medium-sized teams, designing 
and developing enter­prise and embedded Java software; he is a founding member and contributor to three 
worldwide Java and UML industry stan­dards. Max's primary research interests lie in distributed systems 
and software engineering for the Web; in particular, Web APIs and services, mashups, Web 2.0, cloud computing, 
SOA (service­oriented architecture), social software, and Agile methods and practices. His most recent 
research project at IBM Almaden re­sulted in an internal cross-cloud (public and private) management 
and scaling Web-based platform. Max is active participants and contributor to communities related to 
Ruby, Ruby on Rails, and Agile methods and practices, inside and outside of IBM. Reach Max via his Web 
site (www.maximilien.com) and blog (blog.maximilien.com). 5. Contest Format Before the Event, Contestants 
will have the opportunity to submit their ideas to ooplsa-idol@googlegroups.com. The Judges will review 
the submissions and the best 5 will be invited to present their innovation idea at the Event. During 
the Event, each Contestant will be given 5 minutes to present their idea to the Judges and OOPSLA audience. 
The Judges will have up to 2 minutes each to comment on the presen­tation. The Judges will select the 
top 3, and the OOPSLA audi­ence will select the winner from the final 3 choices.
